reviews.review_msg: He's a good guy and cares about the class and students. Very interesting topics and he brought lecture guests that create a sense of dynamism.

I really enjoyed taking Professor Moen's class. His lectures made sense, and he just had a way of saying things that really clicked with me. Your grade depends a lot on your TA but he bumps grades up if he thinks they graded too harshly. Your grade is mainly dependent on the midterm and final, the rest is participation and one activity + write up.

this class becomes the easiest class ever once you get used to his lecture style. he tends to get off topic, but his rants are usually very entertaining. the test questions are all short/long answer, but imo, thats the easiest way to snatch high marks. his slides are lacking in detail, but if youre interested in the topics, youll do just fine

Despite the lack of organisation and cohesiveness in his lectures, I actually had fun listening. You can tell he has a lot of passion in his work and he has a lot to say. It is kind of hard to get notes, but it is possible. While most of his grades are judged by exams and are graded by harsh TAs, he will gladly bump you up.

He doesn't explain any definitions of terms even though it's a 100-level course and his slides are too packed with information. He used many acronyms without explaining what they were, and his speech was quite different from his slide, which confused me. In general, the content wasn't really hard but profs made it a lot harder.

Alex is a great guy, however, the way he taught the course was not great. I did not find his lectures, slides, or readings useful as they were unclear and outdated, hard to read and understand. Course description might sound interesting, but don't take it unless you have to. Shout out to Richard , he's a great TA, really helpful

exams are based on incoherent readings from the 60s, and his lecture slides, which are supposed to guide you through the readings, are just as bad. They contain very little info with abbreviations no one understands. He's also kinda problematic IMO, saying social justice is “not as important as [we] think it is”?? Shoutout to TAs doing overtime lol

Professor Moens was a good professor and I enjoyed his lectures and tutorials. My biggest critiques would be the final exam because the questions didn't relate as well to content learned compared to the midterm questions. This made my mark drop from an A- to a B- .... Additionally, the marking for tutorials seemed harsher than most classes.

He is really great and genuinely engaging to listen to. We had a few guest lecturers to enhance the lessons and the grading organization is totally fair and manageable. Literally just memorize the key points in the lecture notes and readings and some history details for the tests.
Super passionate prof. Can be a tough marker on the quizzes but otherwise very fair.

good lecturer and i found that everything he said in class was easy to remember but i had trouble keeping up with which topic we were on. quizzes not too hard but you can't get a 10 simply by answering the Qs, need to add at least 4 points relating to the rest of the course. made us read a whole book in 2 days, but tests are all on lectures.

This a prof who goes the extra mile for his students. Very knowledgeable, really helps to expand your critical thinking skills. Lectures are easy to keep up with, engaging public speaking voice and fair assignments.

Amazing lecture pace/passion, like a preacher of international relations. Best in poli sci at SFU. Deep knowledge of security, NATO, US foreign policy. Always goes out of his way for students, cares about engagement and gives students unparalleled access to his professional contacts.  Very respectful of all views, wants his students to succeed

His lectures were sort of scattered all over the place; one day we'd talk about economics and politics, next day the rise of China, then again economics and politics again. My notes had large gaps. His tests were fairly easy. World Order is an interesting read but everything you need to know is in lecture. Pretty easy class but dry at times

I swear this guy only teaches because he's lonely. Week 2 he went on a rant about how no one was visiting him in his office hours and was gonna take away points from our participation marks because quote" I'm not a perfect prof you should have questions after lectures." Like wtf man??? Also his late penalty is insane and offers no extensions.

Professeur Vllasi is an excellent professeur! He gives interesting lectures but does require you to participate and will not move on from a question until someone does. He has many opportunities for Extra Credit within the class and Statecraft was really enjoyable (take the Railway) HA! Participation really matters in tutorial, make sure you speak
I took POL141 and POL200W with Vllasi and received A for both. Amazing lectures with totally understandable class policies.

Vllasi is very professional and strict but once he warms up a bit he is a very caring professor. This class was extremely interesting to take and his lectures were always very engaging. Dr.Vllasi is always willing to help students who have questions and starts really interesting conversations. Would definitely recommend taking this course with him.

I think Vllasi is a great prof and definitely, one of my favorites. I can see why some may not like him because of his no-phone policy however his lectures actually teach you because he is invested in what he teaches. He also gives EXTRA CREDIT. The only thing that sucks is that he forces students to participate in lectures even if nobody wants to.

idk why his ratings low. Lectures are average, and you can do well in the course if you skip them. Statecraft was well managed and he genuinely seems like he wants his students to succeed. Comes off intimidating at first, but welcomes questions and fosters an environment of learning. Assignments and exams were all fair, no surprises at all.

Exams are textbook heavy. Assignments are marked tough. In class we werent allowed to take notes. He scaled our midterm and final but seemed he did this because the class did so poorly for a first year course. However, I did enjoy the opportunities for extra credit.

Found Dr. Vllasi intimidating at the beginning of the semester, but over time I became less afraid. He seems judgmental and has high standards. However, his class is fair and exams aren't too hard if u use his slides AND the textbook to study (both are important!). Participation matters, so attend tutorial. Statecraft is neat way to apply concepts.

Gave everyone 10 free marks on a midterm because we did not do as well as expected (something I've never seen or heard of in any university class before). The laptop ban in class is inconvenient, but does allow for people to pay closer attention in class. Lots of extra credit assignments throughout the semester. Great prof if you're putting in work

An average professor who started most lectures in an unwelcoming way by criticizing the class. Strong participation is required as it is worth 25%. Laptops were banned halfway through the semester as he makes us rely on the PowerPoint notes he uploads which are not helpful. Although, he does offer a few extra credit assignments!

First time I've seen a professor that has banned laptop use in class, as it was too "distracting" and because he doesn't trust that we are using them to take notes. Changes instructions on the day of the midterm. Notes are not properly uploaded and covers major information with pictures. Yet offered extra credit. Overall, would not take again.

I'll give him this, he's a very unique professor. Didn't allow for use of laptops in his class and insisted we review the notes later, often not until he felt like uploading them. Not a terrible professor just kind of weird and not super welcoming.

Dr. Vlasi is a nice guy, but not a good instructor. His grading criteria is always all over the place and the way he marks is incredibly harsh. For instance, participation is 20% of the grade in one of his classes, and even if you actively participate in a meaningful manner regularly, he'll still shaft you with a barely passing grade.

Vlassi is a great prof. Very reasonable marker and has spread out marks so students won't get screwed. Also offered 4.5% bonus marks via 3 assignments in the course. I highly recommend him online as the exams are super easy, especially if you study (I didn't but still did really well). Vlassi cares about his students and sets them up to succeed!

Very nice and shows great insight. He comes across as intimidating at first, but he really does care about his students. I took POL 141 this semester and I will be taking POL 349 with him this spring!

Dr. Dimitrov is an old-school professor: he expects you to know dates and names of treaties. Also, GO TO CLASS! A lot of what he discusses isn't in the book! Exams are fair, but require consistent engagement in the course to excel. His lectures are very enriching, as he is a talented speaker and has a wealth of knowledge.

Professor Dimitrov's lectures are without a doubt the most interesting of any class I've taken. While he provides slides it is very clear he knows exactly what he's talking about and has had hands-on experience in this field. His exams are notably difficult, but the content is so interesting they're not that horrible to study for. Highly rec.

Dr. Hoffman is easily one of my favourite professors at SFU. Amazing lectures. Funny. His knowledge for the class and enthusiasm of each topic is what made him a great professor. 141 is not a tough course and I highly recommend taking it even as an elective

Very funny prof, has engaging lectures. Only reason why it's a 4 and not a 5 is because he is sometimes disorganized, but great in every other aspect. For the full 100% in this class you must do the readings which can be  lengthy and attend lectures because he verbally explains the material with more detail compared to his powerpoint slides.

Dedicated, passionate, and caring individual that enjoys teaching and helping students. Defne is a great communicator and is always available to answer questions during class or after (for a mini 1 on 1 private lesson). Politics and International Relations introductory courses can be cumbersome yet Defne makes the learning experience enjoyable.

Solid choice. Was very accommodating to student feedback. Textbook was "assigned" but her lecture covered all necessary topics (didn't read the text book). So many assigned articles but specified which ones would be tested on.

Fairly solid prof. Felt bad as theonline format seemed to be a new experience for her and she had trouble running the course smoothly, deciding to use PowerPoint for lectures instead of recording software. Accommodation to questions and strengthens concepts through exercises each week, and has many interesting documentaries to watch. Readings vital

She is very communicative with the class which I really liked. She does go through the slides rather quickly but does post her lecture slides on canvas. I liked that she took her time to explain concepts that were hard to understand as a student who did not study statistics and political science before. I highly recommend!
